intro: Dasyglossum funis, commonly known as the long-tongued fig, is a species of flowering plant belonging to the family Moraceae. It is characterized by its unique inflorescence structure, which includes both male and female flowers arranged in a syconium, a specialized type of fig-like structure. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are enclosed within a fleshy, inedible fruit. Dasyglossum funis is native to tropical regions of Africa and is adapted to grow in humid, shaded environments. Its botanical features make it an important component of its native ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and wildlife.
